Award.AbstractNarration:
Cells are the building blocks of life, yet they are themselves a
collection of proteins, small molecules, and solvent, none of which
are, in and of themselves, alive. How living things can arise from the
"behavior" of molecules, which are simply obeying the laws of physics,
is the essential conundrum of modern biology. The rise of scientific
supercomputing has offered the chance to study living systems at the
levels of atoms, cells, and all levels in between.  With Blue Waters,
it is now possible to take the most critical step from inanimate to
animate matter by describing assembly and cooperation of thousands of
macromolecules made of billions of atoms.  The ability to explore
living systems via the "computational microscope" of molecular
dynamics simulations has a profound impact not only on the progress of
basic science, but also in the treatment of disease and the
development of drugs.

This project will use Blue Waters to study three types of biomolecular
systems: the microtubules that make up the cell's cytoskeleton, the
chemosensory array that acts as a "bacterial brain", and two highly
relevant retroviruses: HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) and RSV
(Rous sarcoma virus).  The first project will model microtubules, in
their native form, as well as the interactions between the
microtubule, its regulatory partners, and anti-cancer agents.
Simulations of the microtubule and its interactions with drugs can
help drive the development of new microtubule-attacking cancer
therapies.  The HIV part of the virus project builds on prior success
in modeling the full HIV capsid to evaluate the effects of HIV drugs
on capsid stability and to model the essential interactions between
the capsid and host cell factors. Simulations of the HIV capsid
provide the necessary detailed knowledge of the vital infection
process to develop new HIV therapies.  The RSV part of the virus
project has constructed the first model of an intermediate stage in
virus capsid maturation, which will be used to describe the maturation
process of retroviruses may open the doors to a new type of anti-viral
drug which attacks that maturation process.  The chemosensory array
project seeks to answer how input from many chemical sensors on the
bacterial surface are transduced across hundreds of nanometers in the
array, leading the cell to decide if it should continue swimming or
change direction, to adapt to changing environments.  The chemosensory
array is a universal structure in bacteria, but absent in eukaryotes,
offering a new target for antibiotic drugs - a desperately needed
advancement in combating bacterial resistance to current antibiotics.
Each of the projects proposed presents an opportunity for petascale
computing to contribute to mankind?s health and to answer one of
mankind's oldest questions: "What is life?"

POR.DRECONTENT:
A complete description of molecular mechanisms underlying biological processes depends on a dynamical description of the macromolecular systems at a microscopic level. In this project, using the unique computational resources provided by the NSF Blue Waters, we have performed large-scale simulations to investigate the molecular basis of a number of highly relevant processes in diverse biological systems.

Viral Infection. Viruses pose a serious public health threat, causing death to millions of people each year. Large-scale molecular simulations performed on Blue Waters, in close collaboration with leading experimental labs in structural virology, enabled us to develop the first atomic-resolution structural model for the HIV viral capsid (the virus shell; cover article in Nature). Using extended simulations on this computationally developed model we investigated how the viral capsid might interact with the cellular proteins in the host cell and how antiviral drugs interfere with this key process in viral infection. The resulting model and insight provided by the simulations are highly relevant to rational design of next-generation antiviral drugs against HIV and other viruses sharing the same capsid architecture.

Bacterial Chemotaxis. In another project, we studied the signaling proteins that are involved in guiding bacteria toward food sources (or away from toxic material), a process known as chemotaxis. We used molecular simulations to study the atomistic details of sensory signal transduction within chemosensory complex of the gut bacterium E. coli. Integrating existing crystallographic and biochemical structural data with molecular simulations we constructed an atomic-level model of the complete chemotaxis receptor, which was used to investigate fundamental aspects of signal transduction and biological adaptation. Our simulations, in conjunction with extensive mutagenesis data from our collaborators, reveal critical structural aspects of the key control region and suggest a novel signaling mechanism involving the motion of some of the structural elements.

Molecular Motors. Molecular motor proteins are molecular machines that convert chemical energy from ATP into mechanical work. They play key roles in a wide range of biological processes, including transcription, and transport of materials in and out of the cell. The chemo-mechanical energy transduction in motor proteins remains poorly characterized for the majority of systems, primarily due to the structural complexity of molecular machines. To tackle this problem, we employed large-scale molecular simulations performed on Blue Waters to characterize the structural changes underlying motor action of molecular motors at an atomic level. Combining our simulation results with experimental studies at multiple collaborating laboratories around the world, we provided microscopic views on the function of two molecular motors, namely, the molecular details of the stepping mechanism of dynein during cargo transport along the cytoskeleton inside the cell, and the chemical details of how ATP energy is transformed into a rotary motion in a ring-shaped hexameric protein-degrading motor (ClpX) to unfold and prepare proteins for degradation.

Designing Cellulosomes. Cellulosomes are highly efficient cellulose-degrading molecular machines. Crucial to their function are sca?olds consisting of highly homologous protein domains, which serve both to coordinate other enzymes and to anchor the microbe to its substrate. Using large-scale and extended simulations on Blue Waters, we demonstrate a strategy that can be used to ?ne-tune mutations that potentially change the mechanostability of the protein domains. Considering the vast number of cellulosomal constituents yet to be explored, the combination of techniques presented here can potentially accelerate the probing and design of sca?olding domains, starting from nothing more than their genetic code, presenting new opportunities in molecular engineering and biotechnology.

Microtubulin. Microtubules are a major component of the cellular cytoskeleton, important for maintaining cell structure, intracellular cargo transport, and cell division. They are also a major site of action for the anticancer drug, taxol, as well as other pharmacological agents. In this project, we used Blue Waters to simulate how nucleotide binding and hydrolysis lead to microtubule assembly and disassembly, in order to study the molecular mechanism of the stabilizing effect of taxol. The simulations also revealed specific bending and twisting motions that may contribute to the function of this important structural protein.

 

These projects were enabled using our Petascale software (VMD and NAMD) developed and disseminated widely by our group to a broad scientific community via our heavily visited web site www.ks.uiuc.edu (~30,000 unique visitors/month). VMD and NAMD continue to be widely used, with ~110,000 unique registered users for VMD, and ~28,000 for NAMD. Our extensive training efforts have reached (more than 1,100) researchers (graduate students, postdocs, faculty members, and industrial scientists) via our hands-on workshops (currently more than 55) and our online library of tutorials and case studies (>1,700 pages of self-study material). VMD has become popular in high school and entry-level college education, a development that we will continue to fully promote and support.
